prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for ending free friend rides in my car?
My friend always hops rides everywhere in my car. I fill up the tank and pick him up at his house and drop him back off safely at home. This past weekend he put 10 in gas because I forgot my purse home and yesterday he asked me back for it. He has ridden in my car hundreds of times without putting gas. Am I an asshole for saying find your way around in the future?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the "AITA" (Am I the Asshole) post is in the wrong for ending free rides for their friend. The situation is that the friend has been using their car multiple times without contributing to gas, except once when they put in $10 after the author forgot their purse. The author then told the friend to find their own way around.

First, I need to consider the dynamics here. The friend has been using the car for hundreds of rides without paying gas, which is a recurring cost. The author is covering all the expenses. The friend only contributed once when reminded, which might be a one-time exception. The author is now ending the arrangement, which could be seen as a reasonable boundary setting.

But wait, maybe there's more to it. Is there an expectation of reciprocity? If the author's friend is relying on these rides, suddenly stopping could cause inconvenience. However, the author is the one who owns the car and is paying for gas, so they have the right to set their own boundaries. The friend isn't being forced to use the car, just that the author isn't willing to continue covering the costs.

Also, the friend putting in $10 might not be enough. If the cost of gas for those hundreds of rides is much higher than $10, then the friend isn't contributing fairly. The author might feel that their costs are not being shared, hence ending the arrangement. 

On the other hand, maybe the author should have communicated this expectation earlier. However, it's not uncommon for informal arrangements to be one-sided, especially among friends. The author isn't obligated to provide rides, so deciding to stop isn't necessarily being an asshole. The key is whether the author's action was unfair or overly harsh. Since they are maintaining their own boundaries and costs, it's reasonable.

So, the answer would be B (No), the author isn't in the wrong. They have the right to stop providing free rides without contributing gas. The friend's reliance doesn't obligate the author to continue if they don't want to.
